Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Grant: Trojan STEM II - Moving From Restructuring to Implementation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Virginia State University's T-STEM II is a comprehensive educational project whose objectives are closely aligned with VSU's strategic goals and the lessons learned from the first implementation project. The T-STEM II project seeks to 1) improve undergraduate STEM research infrastructure; 2) increase the number of students joining a graduate program in STEM within one year of graduation; and 3) increase the enrollment of African American male students in STEM disciplines. To achieve these goals VSU will: establish an Office of Undergraduate Research to strengthen further the undergraduate research foundation; create an Undergraduate Research Mentoring Program that will train graduates to become life-long learners and skilled communicators; conduct a Summer Research Institute to improve students' ability and enthusiasm in conducting in-depth scientific research; conduct GRE preparation to prepare students for admission to graduate programs; have High School Internships to improve participants' knowledge of research in STEM; and conduct a Pre-college Institute to improve students' knowledge on applications of STEM in real life.
The project includes strategies and activities to advance discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training and learning; broaden participation of underrepresented groups; and enhance infrastructure for research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Increased the number of students who enrolled in a graduate program in STEM within one year of their graduation from an average of 6.1 (total of 37 students between 2004 and 2009) to an average of 19.3 (total of 116 students between 2010-2015) for VSU STEM programs;
  2. Increased the enrollment of African American males in STEM from an average of 322 (between 2004 and 2009) to an average of 512 (between 2010-2015). We achieved an average of 50% male and 50% female enrollment in STEM within the past five years.
  3. The Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR) was established with purpose of coordinating T-STEM II activities with all other STEM projects at VSU. In addition, the OUR provides valuable administrative assistance to small STEM grants. It also helps students to pursue research opportunities at Virginia State University; research-intensive institutions; national research laboratories; and private research facilities. This office received support from the University administration. Currently, the University provides a suite with an office for an administrative assistant, a large office for the director, and a large conference room in the newly renovated Hunter McDaniel Building. The suite is equipped with an overhead projector, a large plotter for printing posters, and other office supplies/equipment.
  4. The project placed seventy- three (73) students into an outside external internship. Twelve (12) students went to government research facilities [NBL (2), NASA (4), URISI (1), ORNL (4), USDA (1) and VDOT (19)] and. Twelve (12) students went to private industries [Genworth, Boston Scientific, EPT Incorporated, Dominion Power and CCAMP].; Sixteen (16) students attended the summer internships at research intensive institutions [Michigan State (2), Barkley (1), Princeton (3), San Jose (1) and University of Hilo Hawaii (9)].  Fourteen (14) students participated in the Summer Field Studies program in Paramaribo, Suriname and at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society and the American Museum of Natural History's Southwestern Research Station in Arizona. Of the seventy-three students placed in these internships, From these students, thirty-one (31) are still enrolled at VSU; forty two (42) have graduated with a bachelor’s degree; four (4) are in an MS Program; two (2) have graduated with an MS degree; and one (1) has earned a PhD degree.
  5. T-STEM II supported a total of 729 students’ presentations at the national conferences and symposia.
  6. The project also supported several workshops and seminars.  ) T-STEM II sponsored faculty development workshops on student outcomes, assessment, and continuous improvement for engineering and computer science faculty.  Accreditation Board of Engineering and Technology (ABET), the accrediting agency for these programs, requires an assessment and continuous improvement process, and all VSU engineering and computer science programs are accredited. In addition, the project sponsored more than sixty (60) research/development workshops/seminars. Approximately thirty-five (35) STEM faculty participated regularly in these seminars. Fifteen out of sixteen STEM faculty who were active in the HBCU-UP project earned tenure and promotion, four of these were promoted to the rank of professor.
  7. A total of 586 students have participated in T-STEM I and T-STEM II of which 390 have already earned a STEM BS degree, with a five-year graduation rate of 90%. One hundred nineteen (124) of these graduates pursued STEM graduate education and forty-seven (52) of them have earned their MS degree so far.  Eleven (13) of the MS graduates went on to pursue a PhD degree, and four of those have already received their doctorate degree. Currently, there are 131 students still enrolled in a VSU STEM undergraduate degree program, fifty nine (59) enrolled in a STEM MS degree program, and eight still pursuing a PhD degree.  
  8. Since the implementation of the T-STEM II, VSU STEM graduation rates have improved from an average of 70 graduates per year to an average of 147 for the past four years. The current VSU five-year graduation rate is 44%, and VSU ranked 10th among all the HBCUs [14].
  9. T-STEM II played a major role in the assistance of STEM faculty in securing grants from industry and federal agencies as follows: $50K from Honeywell, $250K from the VA Department of Transportation, and $150K from the Federal Highway Administration.  In each of the grants, at least one of the T-STEM II senior personnel was directly involved.
  10. T-STEM II Increased the enrollment of African American male students in STEM disciplines; established research and education collaborations with students from other HBCUs; collaborated with Honeywell, DuPont, VDOT, and EPT in research internship and pre-college education; closed some of the gender/ethnic human resources gaps that exists in the national STEM workforce.   

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2017
Modified by: Ali A Ansari
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Increased the number of students who enrolled in a graduate program in STEM within one year of their graduation from an average of 6.1 (total of 37 students between 2004 and 2009) to an average of 19.3 (total of 116 students between 2010-2015) for VSU STEM programs; Increased the enrollment of African American males in STEM from an average of 322 (between 2004 and 2009) to an average of 512 (between 2010-2015). We achieved an average of 50% male and 50% female enrollment in STEM within the past five years. The Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR) was established with purpose of coordinating T-STEM II activities with all other STEM projects at VSU. In addition, the OUR provides valuable administrative assistance to small STEM grants. It also helps students to pursue research opportunities at Virginia State University; research-intensive institutions; national research laboratories; and private research facilities. This office received support from the University administration. Currently, the University provides a suite with an office for an administrative assistant, a large office for the director, and a large conference room in the newly renovated Hunter McDaniel Building. The suite is equipped with an overhead projector, a large plotter for printing posters, and other office supplies/equipment. The project placed seventy- three (73) students into an outside external internship. Twelve (12) students went to government research facilities [NBL (2), NASA (4), URISI (1), ORNL (4), USDA (1) and VDOT (19)] and. Twelve (12) students went to private industries [Genworth, Boston Scientific, EPT Incorporated, Dominion Power and CCAMP].; Sixteen (16) students attended the summer internships at research intensive institutions [Michigan State (2), Barkley (1), Princeton (3), San Jose (1) and University of Hilo Hawaii (9)]. Fourteen (14) students participated in the Summer Field Studies program in Paramaribo, Suriname and at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society and the American Museum of Natural History's Southwestern Research Station in Arizona. Of the seventy-three students placed in these internships, From these students, thirty-one (31) are still enrolled at VSU; forty two (42) have graduated with a bachelor?s degree; four (4) are in an MS Program; two (2) have graduated with an MS degree; and one (1) has earned a PhD degree. T-STEM II supported a total of 729 students? presentations at the national conferences and symposia. The project also supported several workshops and seminars. ) T-STEM II sponsored faculty development workshops on student outcomes, assessment, and continuous improvement for engineering and computer science faculty. Accreditation Board of Engineering and Technology (ABET), the accrediting agency for these programs, requires an assessment and continuous improvement process, and all VSU engineering and computer science programs are accredited. In addition, the project sponsored more than sixty (60) research/development workshops/seminars. Approximately thirty-five (35) STEM faculty participated regularly in these seminars. Fifteen out of sixteen STEM faculty who were active in the HBCU-UP project earned tenure and promotion, four of these were promoted to the rank of professor. A total of 586 students have participated in T-STEM I and T-STEM II of which 390 have already earned a STEM BS degree, with a five-year graduation rate of 90%. One hundred nineteen (124) of these graduates pursued STEM graduate education and forty-seven (52) of them have earned their MS degree so far. Eleven (13) of the MS graduates went on to pursue a PhD degree, and four of those have already received their doctorate degree. Currently, there are 131 students still enrolled in a VSU STEM undergraduate degree program, fifty nine (59) enrolled in a STEM MS degree program, and eight still pursuing a PhD degree. Since the implementation of the T-STEM II, VSU STEM graduation rates have improved from an average of 70 graduates per year to an average of 147 for the past four years. The current VSU five-year graduation rate is 44%, and VSU ranked 10th among all the HBCUs [14]. T-STEM II played a major role in the assistance of STEM faculty in securing grants from industry and federal agencies as follows: $50K from Honeywell, $250K from the VA Department of Transportation, and $150K from the Federal Highway Administration. In each of the grants, at least one of the T-STEM II senior personnel was directly involved. T-STEM II Increased the enrollment of African American male students in STEM disciplines; established research and education collaborations with students from other HBCUs; collaborated with Honeywell, DuPont, VDOT, and EPT in research internship and pre-college education; closed some of the gender/ethnic human resources gaps that exists in the national STEM workforce.
